For the first system, $2x = 3y = -z$:
We can write this system in parametric form, letting $t$ be the parameter for $x$. Thus, we get:
$$x = t,\ y = \frac{2}{3}t, \text{and } z = -2t.$$
This implies that the direction vector associated with the first line is $(\Delta x, \Delta y, \Delta z) = (1, \frac{2}{3}, -2)$. To make calculations easier later, multiply by 3 to clear fractions: $(3, 2, -6)$.

\[ y_1 = 2 - t, \]
\[ z_1 = 3 + 4t. \]

For Line 2 passing through Q(4,1,-3) with direction vector d₂ = ⟨1,0,-1⟩, the parametric equations are:
\[ x_2 = 4 + t, \]
\[ y_2 = 1, \]
\[ z_2 = -3 - t. \]

subanswer.text: To determine the direction vector of each line, let us first write them as parametric equations involving a common parameter t such that any point P($a$, $b$, $c$) lying on Line L satisfies x=$at$, y=$bt$, z=$ct$:   $$LineL_{1}:\begin{cases}&2t=-z\\&-\dfrac{-z}{2}=t,\end{cases}$$$$LineL_{2}:\begin{cases}&t=\dfrac{-y}{6}\\&\dfrac{-y}{6}=t.\end{cases}$$From Equation $\Rightarrow {z}_{1}\left({t}^{-2},1,{}−{t}\right)$, it follows ${l}_{1}\perp${m}_{1}. From Eq.$\Rightarrow {\bf l}_{2}\perp{m}_{2}$, so ${\bf l}_{2}$ & ${\bf m}_{1}$ aren’t parallel nor orthogonal neither antiparallel since no pairwise dot product equals zero ($0$). Thus those lines do not lie within same space dimension—they represent planes rather than straight lines.<|end_of_document|> I apologize, but your question appears incomplete.
